Idiom (Ligurian): A l’é comme andâ in sciô caruggio de Zena
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: It’s like going into the maze of Genoa — describes a confusing or complicated situation.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: It’s a confusing or difficult situation.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to the narrow, twisting alleys (caruggi) of Genoa’s old town.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Ligurian): [a lˈe kume anˈda in ʃu kaˈrud͡ʒu de ˈzena]
First Example Sentence: Quello lavô a l’é comme andâ in sciô caruggio de Zena: ti te perdi subìto!
Second Example Sentence: O discorso de u sindicò a l’é comme andâ in sciô caruggio de Zena.
Third Example Sentence: Cöse, t’æ capìo? A l’é comme andâ in sciô caruggio de Zena!

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Verb phrase; idiomatic verb with indirect object
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To make things worse; to aggravate a bad situation.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Maritime origin — literally ‘to add salt to the tide’.
First Example Sentence: Invece de aiutâme, t’æ dâto o ciù a-a mæza!
Second Example Sentence: Quello l’é sempre bon a dâ o ciù a-a mæza.
Third Example Sentence: No sta dâ o ciù a-a mæza, lasciémmo stâ così!

Idiom (Ligurian): Stâ co-o nasciu in sciâ finestra
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To be nosy; to meddle in others’ affairs.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To intrude or be overly curious.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from traditional village gossipers watching from their windows.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Ligurian): [sta ku u ˈnaʃu in ʃa fiˈnestra]
First Example Sentence: A l’é sempre lì a stâ co-o nasciu in sciâ finestra!
Second Example Sentence: Eugènia a stâ co-o nasciu in sciâ finestra tuttu o giornò.
Third Example Sentence: Mi no stægo co-o nasciu in sciâ finestra, mi lavoru!

Idiom (Ligurian): A l’é comme un figgeu de scignæ
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone mischievous or hard to control.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: A very naughty or restless child.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional comparison with a monkey’s child — playful and uncontrollable.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Ligurian): [a lˈe kume un fiˈʤeu de ʃiˈɲæ]
First Example Sentence: A mæ figlietta a l’é comme un figgeu de scignæ, no se ferma un momento!
Second Example Sentence: L’é sempre in gîro, comme un figgeu de scignæ.
Third Example Sentence: Gh’é chi rumôu, comme un figgeu de scignæ in casa!

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To keep something secret or hidden.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Literally ‘to keep the cat under the cloak’, implying secrecy.
First Example Sentence: O l’ha tegnûo o gattô sott’a tocca finché no l’é stæto tardi.
Second Example Sentence: Ti tegnî sempre o gattô sott’a tocca, eh?
Third Example Sentence: No se peu tegnî o gattô sott’a tocca per sempre.

Idiom (Ligurian): A l’é comme un vento de tramontâ
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Something sudden and intense but short-lived.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to the cold northern wind typical of Liguria.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Ligurian): [a lˈe kume un ˈventu de tramunˈta]
First Example Sentence: O mæ amore a l’é comme un vento de tramontâ.
Second Example Sentence: A passion a l’é comme un vento de tramontâ, a passa presto.
Third Example Sentence: A felicità a l’é comme un vento de tramontâ: bella ma corta.

Idiom (Ligurian): Ciamâ i pesci in sciâ riva
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To shout or protest in vain.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Fishermen’s slang — calling fish ashore, i.e., doing something pointless.
First Example Sentence: Ti ciammi i pesci in sciâ riva se pensi che t’ascoltan.
Second Example Sentence: Gh’é chi ciamma i pesci in sciâ riva ogni giorno in te l’uffìsio.
Third Example Sentence: A lamentâ senza cambiâ ninte l’é comme ciamâ i pesci in sciâ riva.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To make a fuss without reason.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Alludes to making foam without the sea — fuss without substance.
First Example Sentence: No fâ e sciume senza mæ, l’é ninte!
Second Example Sentence: Gh’é sempre chi o fâ e sciume senza mæ pe ninte.
Third Example Sentence: A mamma a fâ e sciume senza mæ ogni votta ch’a vê tardi.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To be involved in many things, often with hidden influence.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To be involved in various matters.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Originates from baking — one’s hands literally in dough.
First Example Sentence: O l’ha sempre e man in pasta, ghe n’é de tùtte e sorte.
Second Example Sentence: Chi o l’ha e man in pasta o sa sempre tùtto.
Third Example Sentence: Mi no vòggio avéi e man in pasta in sta storia.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To lose one’s mind or act irrationally.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To go crazy or lose control.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: From ‘lights’—symbolic of sanity; losing lights means losing reason.
First Example Sentence: Se continuo coscì, mi veggo andâ in scî lûxe!
Second Example Sentence: Gh’é chi o l’é già andæto in scî lûxe da anni.
Third Example Sentence: T’æ visto Gianni? O l’é quasi andæto in scî lûxe co-o stress.
